channel.title: Spring JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [SOCIALFB-48] Facebook User can't Sign in RevokedAuthorizationException
item.description:
Not sure how exactly this happens, but it does. How can this happen when they grant permission right before the GET method is called?

12-02-2011 5:22:52 PM (POST) - http://www.pixoto.com/signin/facebook

{scope:email,publish_stream,offline_access}

(200 - 3 ms)
12-02-2011 5:23:59 PM (GET) - http://www.pixoto.com/signin/facebook?code=AQCQiMCojEDflQETEJ81OAVd29otg2h8L9keSTWSvxKAM6Xs6pA22mgc7NpTLqqn6M9FF6givMlSI2szmSWGDxqF-i4GsvsZo6shL85Os7THr4yUkghlmNqwrjWxokZAfGB52_M8FgP4WuVy4jeVNzzPuJhSSDg8Jvp12ilVpHFdtP2VUgVgeoGmf3PjXd_xOkQ (200 - 292 ms) org.springframework.web.util.NestedServletException: Request processing failed; nested exception is org.springframework.social.RevokedAuthorizationException: The authorization has been revoked.
item.summary: Facebook User can't Sign in RevokedAuthorizationException

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
There are 2 things that could trigger this exception:

  • The user changes their password
  • The access token doesn't have offline_access permission and the user logs out of Facebook

And, per FB's documentation (but not experienced in reality), the user revokes authorization.

FacebookErrorHandler throws that exception when it encounters an error from Facebook with a specific message. The messages it looks for are:

  • "The session has been invalidated because the user has changed the password."
  • "The session is invalid because the user logged out."
  • "has not authorized application"

Under no other circumstance will that exception be thrown. So, it's clear that if you're seeing a RevokedAuthorizationException, then the Graph API has returned an error structure with one of those in the message field. I can't say for certain why Facebook did that, though.

Is there any more info you can provide that might shed some light on why FB might be giving such an error?

As mentioned in my previous comment, I am unable to reproduce this problem. Furthermore, RevokedAuthorizationException occurs under a very small set of circumstances, all of which are triggered by specific messages coming back from Facebook. It's unclear why Facebook is sending those messages, but it's likely either a quirk in Facebook or a quirk in the application code. Therefore, pending further details, I'm closing this issue as "Cannot Reproduce".

In the past DAY, this exception has occurred 6 times. It is definitely a problem because it is occurring during the sign up process. It should be impossible to get a RevokedAuthorizationException from the sign up process because the credentials should be refreshed. Note, I probably get a round 1 thousand facebook sign ins a day.

Sorry for the delayed reply. I had a sport injury and have been offline waiting for it to heal. I will be more responsive to this ticket in the future.

For this ticket to be resolved, at a minimum a proper way of handling this via the ProviderSignInController should be specified. Perhaps the ProviderSignInController should redirect the user BACK to facebook and ask for authentication again.

Scott: I'll have to consider your suggestion to redirect back in the case of an error. It sounds good on the surface, but I want to weigh any potential side-effects (what if this were an OAuth 1 provider? Could I do that without first also getting a new request token?). If I were to do that, it would be an improvement...not a bug...and I'd open a separate issue for it.

For this issue, I'd really like to get to the bottom of why the RevokedAuthorizationException is being thrown. Is there a more complete stack trace you could share? I'm not sure if it'd help or not, but it might. And, I know that this is somewhat unpredictable (6 times out of 1000, as I understand it), but if you could help me try to nail down a way to reproduce it, that'd be helpful too. Perhaps throwing some load at the app will uncover the bug? Without a reproduceable test, we'll never know if it's fixed or if we're just getting lucky.

One thing that might be helpful is if we could work against some common application code. I'm not suggesting that you share the pixoto code (unless you want to), but maybe you could put together just enough of an application (or tweak one of the existing samples) to reproduce this, then I could run it on my end as needed to nail down the problem.
Also, is there any apparent correlation between the errors seen here and those from SOCIALFB-47?

Here is a complete stack trace for a RevokedAuthorizationException:

Nothing special about my code as it uses the default signin controller:

    <bean class="org.springframework.social.connect.web.ProviderSignInController" autowire="constructor">
 
        <constructor-arg name="connectionFactoryLocator" ref="connectionFactoryLocator" />
 
        <constructor-arg name="signInAdapter" ref="signInAdapter" />
 
        <property name="applicationUrl" value="${social.applicationUrl}" />
 
        <property name="signInUrl" value="/" />
 
        <property name="postSignInUrl" value="/welcome" />
 
    </bean>

If you want to see anything else, let me know.

"Perhaps throwing some load at the app will uncover the bug?" Possibly, but it could also just be some sort of random Facebook thing.
I would just like some way of handling this gracefully rather than showing my users an Exception message.

The version of Spring Social I am working against is here:
https://github.com/pixoto/spring-social/tree/gae

It has 2 tweaks/hacks. One increases the timeouts of the http requests and the other makes ProviderSigninAttempt transient so I can rebuild it upon use.
I would say zero correlation with SOCIALFB-47 because they happen at different time intervals and SOCIALFB-47? happens more frequently (16 times as opposed to 6 in the last 1 day, 23:42:18

Thanks for the responses. I agree that handling it gracefully is a good thing, but would still like to do some due diligence and try to figure out if there is an explanation for the problem. If it is a random Facebook thing, then we can hand off what we learn to the FB platform team and see if they can fix it.

The stack trace was helpful, BTW. It tells me that the error you're getting from Facebook is one where the message part says something like "The authorization has been revoked. Reason: Error validating access token:

{token}

has not authorized application

{app ID}

". This is the error that I'd expect to get if I'm using a once-valid token, but the user has revoked authorization to the application. Of course, the mystery is: Why does it say this when the user has authorized the app just moments before???

Since it happens so infrequently, I'm also wondering if this can be tied to a specific user or handful of users. I'm not sure how to find this out, though, since the user in question hasn't signed in yet and their FB data is not available thanks to the error.

This is also why I'd like to get to the bottom of this problem rather than simply covering it up with a graceful workaround: If it can be linked to one or a few users, then forcing them to go through the authorization again may not work the 2nd (or 3rd, or Xth) time, either. Instead of being greeted with an error page, they'd be gracefully shown the authorization dialog again...but still wouldn't be signed in.

One thing I might consider is handling it more gracefully as you suggested, but logging as much info as I can find should it happen (so that we can continue looking for answers).

I've created SOCIAL-280 to capture the real problem of handling errors more gracefully during the connection process, rather than try to manage 4 separate issues that ultimately are describing the same core problem--a problem that exists within Spring Social's core servlets and isn't technically a Facebook or Twitter problem.

Further work on this issue will be handled under SOCIAL-280, thus I'm closing this issue.
Reopening issue to detach from 1.1.0.M1 (since this was actually a Spring Social Core problem fixed in a separate release).
Re-closing this issue (forgot to re-close it after detaching it from 1.1.0.M1). For original resolution comments, see comment from Dec 19, 2011.
